entries.meaning: A starting or falling back; a rebound; a shrinking.
examples: the recoil of nature, or of the blood

entries.meaning: The state or condition of having recoiled.
examples: The recoil from formalism is skepticism.

entries.meaning: (firearms) The energy transmitted back to the shooter from a firearm which has fired. Recoil is a function of the weight of the weapon, the weight of the projectile, and the speed at which it leaves the muzzle.
An escapement in which, after each beat, the scape-wheel recoils slightly.

verbs.description: recoil (third-person singular simple present recoils, present participle recoiling, simple past and past participle recoiled)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To pull back, especially in disgust, horror or astonishment. [from 16th c.]
examples: He recoiled in disgust when he saw the mess.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, now rare) To retreat before an opponent. [from 14th c.]

examples: The solemnity of her demeanor made it impossible  […]  that we should recoil into our ordinary spirits.

entries.meaning: (of a firearm) To quickly push back when fired
